abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Banking Sector
            Restructuring and Privatization Project is to help Pakistan
            continue implementation of its banking reform program, in an
            aim to achieve a competitive private banking system, strong
            regulatory framework, and an effective banking court system.
            The project components include: 1) the Nationalized
            Commercial Bank (NCB) staff rationalization, to be
            accomplished through a voluntary separation scheme, whereby
            a severance package (consisting of cash compensation
            calculated on the basis of one month pay per year of
            service, plus commutation of all annual leave, pensions, and
            medical benefits) will be provided. The voluntary scheme
            will be complemented by the out-sourcing of non-core staff,
            and leave without pay, but without benefits for those in
            executive levels; 2) a proportional reduction of bank
            branches, will accompany staff rationalization to assure a
            structural, and virtually irreversible reform, namely in the
            Habib Bank Limited (HBL), United Bank Limited (UBL), and
            National Bank of Pakistan (NBP). The cost of this component
            would come mainly from the settlement of long-term leases on
            rented space, and, NCB funds will finance this cost as part
            of counterpart funding; 3) the amalgamation of the National
            Development Finance Corporation (NDFC) into a National Bank
            will entail severance payment costs, and the costs emanating
            from recognition of quasi fiscal costs, embedded in
            NDFC's balance sheet; 4) completion of the Muslim
            Commercial Bank, and Allied Banking Limited privatizations,
            through government divestments for the first, and, taking
            into account the level of insolvency of the second, these
            costs will be financed by the Government, implied in the
            price of remaining shareholding; and, 5) other policy
            measures, such as liberalization of bank branching policy;
            revision of tax policy and administration; amendment of the
            Loan Recovery Act (1997); reform of the National Savings
            Scheme; and discontinuance of the new Foreign Currency
            Deposit scheme.
